item.title: The Left Hand of Darkness
item.description: Imperfect and still utterly perfect. Favorite always. The David Mitchell foreword Picture if you will reading this book when it was published, 1969, the year of Stonewall

item.title: The Dispossessed
item.description: Sublime. Carefully constructed, nuanced, warmly empathetic, passionately human, complex. If you want a rose-colored ideologue that purports to fix problems with simplistic utopias, look elsewhere.

item.title: Clear and Muddy Loss of Love
item.description: This is just what I was in the mood for, a 300+ chapter, 4000 page sapphic slow burn court intrigue. The prose (and/or translation?

item.title: Pagans
item.description: About as beautifully (and concisely) written as you can get for a history book. Fabulous stuff. Some fav lines: —Augustus revived a thing that had barely been invented in his own time: “old-time religion,” rather like the nearly postmodern version of Christianity invented in nineteenth-century America and called “fundamentalism.

item.title: The Lathe Of Heaven
item.description: I can’t remember the last time I read a book with a truly passive protagonist, where his qualities are not his weakness, but his strength.

item.title: The Twice-Drowned Saint
item.description: I don’t even know how the hell to describe this, except amazing. Apparently my unintentional theme lately is biblically accurate angels—see [[books/pet|Pet]], see [[books/exodus 20|Freydís Moon]].
